text: A big shakeup seemingly underway at the Southern Poverty Law Center.
author: mcpli

text:
Literally an hour before the Mueller report, it suddenly got dark and windy in DC and there was a big clap of thunder. Then things cleared up.  

These things may be unconnected - or . . .
author: mcpli

text: Robert Mueller clearly knows next week is reserved for gerrymandering news. #fairmaps
author: mcpli

text: Indeed, one of the additional benefits of putting limits on partisan gerrymandering is that it would help de-incentivize the targeting of communities of color for political gain (something both parties do). #fairmaps 42/
author: mcpli

text: A powerful reminder that people of color are all too often the victims of partisan, as well as racial, gerrymandering. #fairmaps 41/
author: mcpli

text: And as in NC, there was a racial dimension to what happened in Maryland. During the redistricting process, African-American groups proposed a map that would have increased black representation. But Ds rejected that map because it interferred with gerrymandering. #fairmaps 40/
author: mcpli

text: Although Democrats in Maryland were not quite as facially blatant as their counterparts in NC, it did not take much digging in the case to uncover evidence that their primary motive was politics. For example, see this from the plaintiffs' brief. #fairmaps 39/
author: mcpli

text: The result was to transform a map where Democrats had a 6-2 advantage into one where they held a 7-1 advantage. #fairmaps 38/
author: mcpli

text: Indeed, only a handful of comparable districts involved population moves as extensive as MD-6 - and most of those districts were in North Carolina, where Republicans drew a map struck down as a racial gerrymander. #fairmaps 37/
author: mcpli

text: And factually, there is no doubt that something very strange went on in Maryland. Although MD-6 needed slight population adjustments to meet one person, one vote requirements, Maryland Ds went way overboard. #fairmaps 36/ http://www.brennancenter.org/analysis/marylands-extreme-gerrymander …
author: mcpli

text: In the Maryland case, the plaintiffs, who are all Republican voters, contend that Maryland Democrats, who controlled the redistricting process, burdened their First Amendment rights by moving voters around to harm Republican voting strength. #fairmaps 35/
author: mcpli

text: Let's start with the Maryland plaintiffs' legal theory - which is based solely on the First Amendment (in contrast to the NC case which involves equal protection and Elections Clause claims as well). #fairmaps 34/
author: mcpli

text: But enough about procedure! What is the Maryland case about? #fairmaps 33/
author: mcpli

text: The Maryland case is now back at SCOTUS after the trial court heard additional evidence and ruled that the redrawing of Maryland's 6th congressional district in 2011 was, indeed, an unconstitutional partisan gerrymander. #fairmaps 32/
author: mcpli

text: However, rather than reach the merits of the Maryland plaintiffs' partisan gerrymandering claim, the Supreme Court sent the case back to the district court finding that the court had not abused its discretion in declining to block the map. #fairmaps 31/
author: mcpli

text: The case then went up to the Supreme Court a second time last term after the three-judge panel (which had not yet held a trial) declined to block use of the map for the 2018 election. #fairmaps 30/
author: mcpli

text: In his second to last opinion, Justice Scalia held that the claim was not so implausible as to rise to the level of frivolousness and a three-judge panel was convened and ruled 2-1 that the case could go forward. #fairmaps 29/
author: mcpli

text: The first time the case went up to the Supreme Court on the question of whether a partisan gerrymandering claim was so frivolous that it could be dismissed without convening the three-judge panel required in redistricting cases. #fairmaps 28/
author: mcpli

text:
And now onto the Maryland case, which will be the second partisan gerrymandering case the court hears on Tuesday. 

This will be the Maryland case's third trip to the high court. #fairmaps 27/
author: mcpli

text: And though there is statistical evidence in the NC case about how anomalous a 10-3 map is in North Carolina, you don't even really need that. Tell the person on the street a party got 50% of the vote but 23% of the seats & the reaction is likely to be WTF. #fairmaps #ncpol 26/
author: mcpli

text: In some cases where you lack direct evidence, social science can be helpful in identifying anomalous results. But in NC, Rs announced their intent beforehand *in public* and the map they got delivers what they wanted - a durable 10-3 advantage. #fairmaps #ncpol 25/
author: mcpli

text: One note here about social science, which has been a big part of debates about gerrymandering in recent years: It's helpful but not essential in North Carolina. This, in short, is not a case about social science, much less constitutionalizing it. #fairmaps #ncpol 24/
author: mcpli

text: That gives the Supreme Court a lot to work with - the question for the court is which theory best gets at a harm that is pretty manifest but at the same time limits the risk of judicial over-extension into politics. #fairmaps #ncpol 23/
author: mcpli

text: The individual voters in the case also have raised claims under a variety of different parts of the Constitution: the Equal Protection Clause, the 1st Amendment, and the Elections Clause. #fairmaps #ncpol 22/
author: mcpli

text:
I mean the whole purpose of a political party is for like-minded people to be able to organize and win elections. 
But NC Republicans not only put their thumb on the scale, they largely made that task impossible. #fairmaps #ncpol 21/
author: mcpli

text: That's important because whatever the harm to individual voters' rights (an issue that sometimes has been a rabbit hole for the court), the party clearly is a principal target and victim of the gerrymander. #fairmaps #ncpol 20/
author: mcpli

text: For one thing, unlike last term's cases, which were brought exclusively by individual voters, the NC case includes claims brought by the North Carolina Democratic Party. #fairmaps #ncpol 19/
author: mcpli

text: The good news in the North Carolina case is that the court has a lot of theories on the table it can use to curb abuses like those that happened in NC in 2016. #fairmaps #ncpol 18/
author: mcpli

text: But, as we found last year, the new political gerrymandered map just as effectively keeps African-American political power in NC in check as did the racially gerrymandered map. #fairmaps #ncpol 17/   http://www.brennancenter.org/sites/default/files/publications/Extreme%20Gerrymandering%204.24.18.pdf …
author: mcpli

text: This is, after all, a case that originated in the court-ordered redraw of a map found to have discriminated against African-American voters. #fairmaps #ncpol 16/
author: mcpli

text: But though the focus is on partisan effect (this is, after all, a partisan gerrymandering case), it's important not to overlook the racial impact of what happened in NC. #fairmaps #ncpol 15/
author: mcpli

text: You can rightly debate what the best split is - and lots of neutral considerations will affect whether a map is 8-6 one way or 6-8 the other (or some other split). But point is you only get to 10-3 by prioritizing politics above all other considerations. #fairmaps #ncpol 14/
author: mcpli

text: The evidence at the trial court was even more powerful. Among the thousands of simulated maps drawn without regard to partisanship, not one resulted in a 10-3 GOP advantage. #fairmaps #ncpol 13/
author: mcpli

text: And that result is in no way natural or inevitable. Before maps were redrawn in 2011, there were 7 Democrats and 6 Republicans in the NC congressional delegation. #fairmaps #ncpol 12/
author: mcpli

text: And the ruthless effectiveness of their gerrymander got vividly illustrated with the 2018 election, where despite Ds winning roughly half the congressional vote, they remained stuck at the same 3 seats (*NC-9 still pending). #fairmaps #ncpol 11/
author: mcpli

text: If the North Carolina map isn't constitutionally problematic,  it's hard to see what would be. North Carolina Republicans didn't just get caught red-handed robbing the bank, they had a press conference beforehand & said, ' we are going to rob the bank.' #fairmaps #ncpol 10/
author: mcpli

text: Which is not to say that Chief Justice Roberts and/or Justice Alito are 'on board' but rather that the facts of North Carolina are so stark, it is hard for the court to avoid some really threshold constitutional questions. #fairmaps #ncpol 9/
author: mcpli

text: And as importantly, they seemed to think that it would be relatively easy for courts to manage - a critical point because the manageability of any anti-gerrymandering has been a central worry for the court over the years. #fairmaps #ncpol 8/
author: mcpli

text:
Ultimately, both lawyers for WI and MD in last term's cases agreed that expressly requiring favoring a party would be problematic. 

And more importantly, even Chief Justice Roberts & Justice Alito *seemed* to think so. #fairmaps #ncpol 7/
author: mcpli

text: All this is significant because it is the hypothetical asked twice last term by Justice Kennedy about whether requiring favoring one party over the other would be unconstitutional. #fairmaps #ncpol 6/
author: mcpli

text: And not only did they say it, they put in writing requirements that allowed the legislature to consider only maps that gave Republicans a 10-3 advantage. #fairmaps #ncpol 5/
author: mcpli

text: Ordered to redraw the map, NC Republicans unabashedly said they would replace the racial gerrymander with a political gerrymander. No, really, those are the words they used. #fairmaps #ncpol 4/
author: mcpli

text: The North Carolina map being challenged dates to 2016 & replaces an earlier map courts had struck down as a racial - as opposed to partisan - gerrymander (the earlier map drawn in 2011 unconstitutionally packed African-American voters into two districts). #fairmaps #ncpol 3/
author: mcpli

text:
The North Carolina cases will be heard first, so let's start with them. 

And there's both a lot to say and not a lot that needs to be said. That's because what happened in North Carolina was so aggressive & blatant, it really is in a lot of ways an easy case. #fairmaps #ncpol 2/
author: mcpli

text: On Tuesday, partisan gerrymandering returns to SCOTUS when the high court hears arguments in cases challenging North Carolina's and Maryland's congressional maps. A thread. #fairmaps #ncpol 1/
author: mcpli

text: When I saw this tweet, I thought Dan had become a reporter for the Onion, but apparently this is, well, not the Onion . . .

text: And the final brief in the partisan gerrymandering cases (from NC Republicans) is in. Everything now set for oral argument on Tuesday. #fairmaps https://www.brennancenter.org/sites/default/files/legal-work/2019-03-19-Appellants%27%20Reply%20Brief.pdf …
author: mcpli

text: Just watched ‘The Inventor’ on HBO. Even though I knew how the sordid story would end, what a mouth on floor telling. It’s flabbergasting that so many powerful, wealthy people got duped for as long as they did.

author: mcpli

text: .@scotusblog breaks down the arguments in the Virginia racial-gerrymandering case. #fairmaps
author: mcpli

text: And on the partisan gerrymandering front, here's the reply brief the State of Maryland filed ahead of argument next week in the NC/MD gerrymandering cases: https://www.brennancenter.org/sites/default/files/legal-work/2019-03-18-Reply%20Brief%20for%20Appellants.pdf … #fairmaps
author: mcpli

text: Here's the transcript from this a.m.'s SCOTUS argument in the Virginia racial gerrymandering case. https://www.supremecourt.gov/oral_arguments/argument_transcripts/2018/18-281_197d.pdf … #fairmaps
author: mcpli

text: Only 4 out of 24 people arguing at the Supreme Court in March are women (including ⁦@allisonriggs⁩ of @scsj - one of two advocates arguing for plaintiffs in the NC partisan gerrymandering cases).

text: I think the increasing diversity of top House staff is awesome - and I think it is awesome that the NYT decided to write about it. But c’mon, not featuring any Latinos or Asians (in the text or in the photos)???
author: mcpli

text: As a result, the district court has already completed the remedial process and put in place a new map - which subject to how SCOTUS rules will be used in the 2019 elections. That map order here: https://www.brennancenter.org/sites/default/files/legal-work/2019-02-14-361-Memorandum%20Opinion.pdf … #fairmaps 13/
author: mcpli

text: Oh, and although SCOTUS sometimes puts the redrawing of maps on hold while it hears redistricting appeals, it declined to do so in this instance. #fairmaps 12/
author: mcpli

text: To say the least, Monday will an interesting argument time wise, with VA Republicans getting 25 minutes, the Justice Dept. 10 minutes, Mark Herring 10 minutes, and 15 minutes for the plaintiffs in the case. #fairmaps 11/
author: mcpli

text: Though it goes on to argue that the district court didn't get the racial predominance analysis right this time either. #fairmaps 10/
author: mcpli

text: In the mean time, the Trump DOJ also is participating in the case - and agrees that VA Republicans lack standing. #fairmaps 9/
author: mcpli

text: SCOTUS agreed to hear the case, but also asked for briefing on the standing question (whether VA Republicans have the right to be bringing the appeal) - so an added twist for Monday's argument (we'll see how much time the Justice actually spend on it). #fairmaps 8/
author: mcpli

text: But Virginia's Democratic attorney general Mark Herrring did not and instead asserted that the VA House and house speaker lacked standing (i.e. the legal power) to ask for SCOTUS review. His filing here: https://www.brennancenter.org/sites/default/files/legal-work/2018-10-09-State%20Appellees%20Motion%20to%20Dismiss.pdf … #fairmaps 7/
author: mcpli

text: And here things get a bit interesting because the GOP-controlled VA House of Delegates and the speaker of the house, both of whom had intervened in the case, appealed to SCOTUS. #fairmaps 6/
author: mcpli

text: The case then went back to the district court, which held a second trial on whether the 11 Virginia districts were racial gerrymanders. This time, the court found that they were in a decision in June 2018. That opinion here:  https://www.brennancenter.org/sites/default/files/legal-work/BH_v_VABoardofElections_Opinion_06.26.18.pdf … #fairmaps 5/
author: mcpli

text: That first SCOTUS decision: http://www.brennancenter.org/sites/default/files/legal-work/BH_v_VABoardofElections_SC_Opinion_15-680_03.01.17.pdf … #fairmaps 4/
author: mcpli

text: Originally, the district court held that the 11 districts were *not* racial gerrymanders. But in March 2017, SCOTUS reversed that decision, holding that the district court had applied the wrong standard in deciding that race had not predominated. #fairmaps 3/
author: mcpli

text: This is the second trip to SCOTUS for the Virginia racial gerrymandering case. #fairmaps 2/
author: mcpli

text: On Mon, racial (as opposed to partisan) gerrymandering returns to SCOTUS as the court hears the appeal of a decision finding that 11 Virginia house of delegates districts had been unconstitutionally drawn with too much consideration of race. #fairmaps 1/
author: mcpli

text: SCOTUS expands argument time in North Carolina partisan gerrymandering cases to be heard on 3/26. NC will have 35 minutes, the Common Cause plaintiffs 20 minutes, and LWV plaintiffs 15 minutes. #fairmaps #ncpol
